cab.content: MINISTKY OF FOOD. Report for Week ending Wednesday, November 20, 1918. PART I-ACTION TAKEN. Relaxation of Control. It was stated in the House of Commons to-day, in answer to a question by Sir Leo Chiozza Money, that the powers and duties of theFood Controller are limited by statute to the expiration of one year after the termina-tion of the war or to such earlier date as may be fixed by Order in Council. Noarrangement could accordingly l)e made, under these powers, for any permanentcontrol of food. The question whether any part of the control established during thewar could usefully be continued during peace was being considered. Meanwhile thefood position was not such as to render any immediate relaxation of controlpossible. At the meeting of the Consumers' Council on 20th November, on the motion ofMr. Hyndman, a committee was appointed : " To consider the measures taken by the Ministry of Food for the control of prices and distribution of food, and for other purposes during the war period, and to advise whether any, and, if any, which of these measures should be continued in peace time." Owing to the allocation of increased tonnage, the stocks of tea now in the country are very much larger than it was anticipated would be the case. The decision hasconsequently been taken (a) to relax the present restrictions on the quantities of tea which may be obtained by traders, caterers, &c, and be disposed of by retailers to their registered customers; and (b) to suspend further action with regard to the introduction of the stricter scheme of distribution which it had been intended to bring into operation as from 25th January. The Food Controller has decided that the following concessions with regard tothe meat ration may he made for the coming Christmas season : (1) Turkeys, ducks, geese, fowls, chickens, and game are free of the coupon, whether bought from a retailer or, in the form of a meat meal, at a catering establishment, from Monday 16th December to Saturday 4th January. (2) Butcher's Meat. The value of the meat coupon is doubled, in England and Wales, for the week preceding Christmas (which gives the coupons numbered 7 in the current ration book double value during the 10 days of their currency), and in Scotland for the following week (which gives the coupons numbered 8 the double value). This concession also applies to both retailers and caterers ; the classes of meat included are beef, veal, mutton, lamb, pork, suet, loose fat, tongues, kidneys, and ox-skirt. With the concurrence of the Food Controller, the Royal Commission on the SugarSupply proposes to make additional Christmas tide issues of sugar to children undersix years, to persons resident in hospitals, workhouses, &c, to Local Food committees in connection with local festivities, and to manufacturers of sugar confectionery,pastries, biscuits, &c. The Imports Board have considered the relaxation of import restrictions on food-stuffs. The Board of Trade have issued a preliminary list of prohibited articles forwhich it is proposed to issue general licences for three months, and this listincludes : Aerated mineral and table waters (unsweetened); almonds and nuts ; cocoa (raw); apples; bananas; bladders, casings and sausage skins, calves vels and rennet; salt. A further list of articles for which, general licences will be issued is under con-sideration. Cable instructions have been sent to both the United States and Canada A (33)6822-3 Pk 1 140 11/18 E & S A. o ship apples freely on private account at commercial rates. Freight rates havealien from 21. 10s. to 11. per barrel. The Food Council. Sir John Beale reported that the Ministry of Shipping were able to arrange freight for the importation of Canadian apples the speedy supply anddistribution of which is very desirable. It was decided to instruct the FruitSupplies Branch to purchase and import up to 20,000 tons on direct account of theMinistry of Food, this direct purchase to be distributed on arrival through ordinarytrade channels and to be additional to and not instead of the importation already sanctioned on private account. An Order fixing maximum prices is to be issued. The Food Controller has decided not to appoint Mr. Reginald Butler as Directorof the Milk Clearing House, but he is to be asked to serve on the Milk Board togetherwith a representative of the Agricultural Organisation Society and a representative ofthe wholesale trade not connected with the United Dairies, Ltd. It was reported that the India Office had agreed to the purchase of the export-able surplus of. the whole range of oilseeds in India, and it was decided that theOilseeds Executive should proceed to purchase. The Financial Secretary lias been authorised to proceed with the financial arrangements relative to the provision of hotel accommodation for the British delegates.to the Peace Conference. Home Supplies Board. The operation of the Feeding Stuffs Scheme and theeffect of the anticipated increase in the amount of offals available to 40,000 tons aweek was reviewed. It was agreed that, subject to further consideration of estimatedresults to be worked out by the Feeding Stuffs Board, it appeared to be advisable toissue an Order that all licences for purchase of offals should be treated as prioritycertificates, leaving the miller free to sell any surplus he may have after meeting thedemands of the ration. Central Agricultural Advisory Council. At a meeting of the Council onNovember J 9th, it was agreed that only fat stock markets in selected districtssuffering hardship should be re-opened rather than all the markets in one area.Several members expressed( the opinion that the congestion in the grass districtswould be completely relieved within a fortnight, and that great credit was due tothe Ministry of Food for its prompt action in dealing with surplus supplies of fatcattle. An announcement as to the measures taken for dealing with the surplus suppliesof pigs was made ; the buying permits issued in any live stock area have been madeavailable also in adjacent areas, thus permitting four or five times as many buyers toenter a market as under the former regulations ; the " per head " charge on all pigsover 170 lbs. live weight has been reduced by 25s. and by corresponding smalleramounts on pigs of less weight. It is hoped that these measures will meet thesituation without any alteration in the Pig Sales Order. The following motion was carried : " The Central Agricultural Advisory Council desires to call the attention of the War Office to the grave danger attending the repatriation of Army horses from France, owing to the prevalence of a malignant form of ophthalmia and other infectious diseases in a more or less epidemic form amongst these horses. It is hoped that special care will be taken to safeguard the interests of horse owners and live stock breeders in the United Kingdom in. reference to this matter." Labour Conference. The Seventh Labour Conference was held at GrosvenorHouse on Saturday, 16th instant. There was a large attendance, over 200 delegatesattending from the various Labour, Trade Union, and Co-operative Organisations inLondon. The chief question before the Conference was the present position of the milksupply in the country. Great feeling was expressed both as to the question of distribution and the price of milk. Mr. H. N. Hyndman, who attended, urged a subsidy so that milk might be brought within the reach of all people earning under31. per week, and the Conference clearly expressed the view that priority schemes were useless so long as the price was so high that it was beyond the reach of familieswho could not afford to buy it. A resolution was proposed and carried practicallyunanimously, that a subsidy should be made, so that the price of milk should bereduced to 6d. per quart, which would enable a priority scheme to become practicable and would achieve a fairer distribution. The constitution of the new Food Control Committees came under [consideration. After considerable discussion the Conference passed the following resolution : " That this Conference expresses its appreciation with the substantial increase of Labour Representation on the newly appointed Food Control Committees insisted upon in the new Order of the Ministry, and trusts the Local Authorities will loyally carry out the instructions contained, in such Order." SUPPLIES AND DISTRIBUTION. Bacon. It is proposed that, until tho position-becomes clearer, there should be no relaxation of the present rules, but that the existing channels, both of supply and distribution, should be maintained. During the past week the civilian consumption of bacon fell off, but it is expected to increase considerably from now onwards, as more popular cuts are being distributed. A good supply of hams has been allotted by the Ministry among the trade, in order to meet the Christmas demand. A considerable amount of imported bacon has been sent from the United Kingdom to France and Belgium to help feed the liberated districts. This amount will be subsequently replaced by France and Belgium. The lard supplies and stocks are ample for the civil requirements. ' , Cereals. The Grain (Prices) Amendment Order, 1918, dated 14th November 191.8, increases the maximum price for barley by 3s. per quarter, when the sale is made to a licensed manufacturer buying for manufacture, or to a recognised dealer buying for resale to a licensed manufacturer. Until 1st January 1919, barley may not be sold for seed at a price exceeding the maximum price under the Grain (Prices) Order. Cocoa. Cocoa has been removed from the list of prohibitive imports for a period of three months. In addition the Board of Trade will allow, during 1919, the importation of raw cocoa from all countries up to 100 per cent, of their imports in 1916. At a meeting of the Cocoa Advisory Committee held on Tuesday, the 19th November, it was unanimously decided by the members of the Committee that the relaxation of cocoa control would be extremely unwise at the present time. Coffee. The coffees of average quality have dropped in price some 10s. or 15s. per cwt. This lowering of prices is due to an understanding arrived at between the trade and the Ministry at the last Coffee Advisory Committee meeting, when the buying brokers agreed to notify this Ministry of their principals within 24 hours of the commence- ment of the sale. This agreement has already commenced to work admirably. Confectionery. A general licence, dated 13th November 1918, under the Sugar (Confectionery) Order, authorises all persons concerned to buy or sell by retail crystallised and glace fruits at a price not exceeding 3^d. per oz. after I5th November. Feeding-stuffs. No immediate alleviation of the present shortage of cakes and meals is anticipated, and there is little, likelihood that it. will be possible for some time to relax any of the restrictions placed on the distribution of these products under the scheme. At the same time, no effort is being spared to obtain supplies wherever they can be obtained. A notice has been issued increasing by 50 per cent, the allowance to pig clubs and small owners of pigs. Meat-There are indications of diminution in the supplies of live stock coming forward. It has already been found necessary to export the surplus from the Northumberland area to Scotland, and reports have been received that there may be difficulty in filling the whole of the army requirements during next week. This diminution of home supplies, however, comes at an opportune time, as it is highly desirable that issues of frozen meat should be made in order to provide accommoda- tion in the stores for the arrivals which may be expected during the next few weeks. As the situation appears at present, some small difficulty may be experienced in finding space for these arrivals, but instructions have been issued that all meat in doubtful condition or in stores which cannot be relied upon to hold the meat in soundcondition shall be issued as speedily as possible. It i3 not intended to retard the supply of home-grown cattle more than hashitherto been the case, and it is also intended to fulfil the promise given by the FoodController that an increased import of live cattle from Ireland shall be permitted. As a result of the shipment of stock fit for slaughter from the areas in the Southof England to the Channel Islands without the permission of the Food Controller, anOrder has been made prohibiting such export except by permit. Potatoes. It is proposed to modify the existing Potato Distribution Scheme onthe following lines: . (a) The grading of potatoes into two grades according to variety will be abolished. (6) The fixed retail prices for potatoes of \\d. per lb. for Grade 1 and Id. per lb. for Grade 2 will be abandoned. (c) Within each zone the grower will be permitted to sell to any person at the price fixed by the Joint Commission of the Board of Agriculture and the Ministry of Food. (d) Wholesale dealers and retail dealers will be permitted to sell on margins as in the Potatoes Order 1917. (e) The export of potatoes from surplus to deficit zones will continue under control as under the present Scheme. (/) Potatoes exported from surplus zones will be graded by the zonal chairman according to quality, and these different grades will be sold in the deficit zones in competition with the potatoes grown in the deficit zone. The modifications in the Scheme abolish the accounting arrangements by whole-sale dealers and simplify the Scheme from the trade point of view without relaxing the control on distribution. ENFORCEMENT OF ORDERS. The prosecutions for the week are as follows : Prosecutions. Convictions.EnglandScotlandWalesIreland Total ------ 850 822 Two sentences of imprisonment were passed, at Southwark and. at the Guildhall. In the Southwark. case, which was an instance of issuing two Ration Books, A. E. Smith, who had been sentenced to a month's hard labour, had an epileptic fit on leaving the Court. The Magistrate, in consideration of his being a discharged soldier in delicate health, remitted the sentence to one of a fine of 107,., to be paid in 21 days, or one months' imprisonment. At the Guildhall, W. Eaton was charged with adding water to milk intended for. sale, pleaded guilty, and was sentenced to one months' imprisonment in the second division. PART II.-SUMMARY OF THE FOOD POSITION. IMPORTS. Imports of the principal foods and feeding-stuffs in the week ended November 16th(161,100 tons) were less satisfactory than those of recent weeks and show a decline of 32,700 tons on those of the preceding week and of 21,400 tons on the average weekly imports in the first 46 weeks of the year 1918. The decrease on the week endedNovember 9th mainly affected oats (decrease 10,600 tons), maize (decrease 14,700 tons),rice (decrease 4,400 tons), sugar (decrease 6,900 tons), and cheese (decrease 3,200 tons).- 437 418- 42 42- 67 .60- 304 302 Very small quantities of barley, cheese, and coffee arrived; on the other hand, theimports of cocoa (increase 2,300 tons) and of tea (increase 5,100 tons) were heavy. Bread and Flour. The bakers' returns for the four weeks ended November 9thshow a fall of 2 per cent, in the quantity of flour used for bread or sold -the declinebeing mainly in the quantity used for bread. The fall is the more remarkable asoccurring at a time of the year when a seasonal increase might have been expected ;nor was the change anticipated by a decline in the quantities delivered from mills and issued to agents (Table B (1)). The stocks in bakers' hands represent 11-1- days'requirements as compared with 12 days' requirements last month and also ayear ago. Meat. The consumption of meat remains at about the same level as in recent weeks, except in Ireland where seasonal supplies of fat stock have been accompaniedby an increase of consumption. In the week ended 9th November 1,500 tons of imported, refrigerated meat were released, as compared with 1,000 tons in precedingweeks, but a large proportion of this (850 tons) consisted of offals and boneless beefwhich are largely used for sausage meat and so fall outside the ration. It was not found necessary to draw on the stocks of home-grown meat in cold storage. Fats.-Table B (1) shows a decrease of butter and margarine entering intoconsumption. Traders' stocks of margarine having been built up to meet thereadjustment of the butter and margarine ration the issues have heen reduced to current requirements. The excess of estimated consumption over domestic rationrequirements (representing a margin for caterers' supplies and losses) is now reducedto 10 per cent. Fish. Supplies of fish at Billingsgate and at several large provincial markets for the week ended 9th November were 3,710 tons, as compared with a weeklyaverage of 5,000 tons for October. . The decrease, however, is not abnormal at thisseason. Supplies at Billingsgate alone were 2,138 tons, as compared with 2,050 tonsin the corresponding week last year. STOCKS. Stocks show little change during the week ended 9th November. Meat (104,200tons) has increased by a further 14,200 tons, Avhile bacon (76,500 tons) has fallen bya further 2,000 tons. Condensed milk (canned) is stationary at the high figure of49,000 tons. COST OF LIVING.
